div.p: Greetings. So that I do not write nothing even now, dear brother, I at least wanted to send greetings and report these few things: The royal envoy passed through here, a man, as it appears, not bad, certainly eloquent and not imprudent.
Another envoy of the king arrived in Solothurn; however, both spoke with me privately, and the one from Solothurn is not approved as much as yours.
We have nothing yet from the assembly.
The Three Leagues did not want to address the matter of Claron from the beginning of the assembly, as had been decreed previously; they claim they have not yet fully consulted on giving a response.
The mediators took this indignantly and ordered a response within a few days; we are therefore waiting to see what will happen.

We have nothing from France, except that rumor spreads that the king entered Lyon with royal pomp on June 12 and was received there magnificently. I would rather hear from you about the Hannibalic soldiers, where they are being led.
The Emperor's commissioners wrote to the prefects of the neighboring Swiss, not to suspect anything sinister, that all is well, and may all indeed be well.
I am always as I am, in poor health, and yet I must continue until I succumb. The wife of Egli, otherwise a good man, will pay the penalty for insolence and stubbornness.

Good Egli will bear a heavy burden; for his father, along with his mother, awaits his arrival with great longing. His remaining relatives are poor; they will drain him and in the meantime will not show him any gratitude. He would have lived much more comfortably and peacefully with you; but while avoiding Scylla, we fall into Charybdis.
May the Lord bless you and your family. Farewell.

The royal envoy reported amazing things about your fellow member; see to it again and again that you handle him so that he causes no harm, and that a hidden evil, as much as possible, does not erupt and an open discord among you does not harm the cause.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the church of Chur, my esteemed lord and dearest brother. Chur.
